{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3315177,"name":"","username":"manso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/e99b99/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-22T16:36:02.037Z","cooked":"

We have a couple commands that use limit switches to know when these commands should stop/begin or do something else. We periodically update its status on SmartDashboard

They work flawlessly in teleop mode, however when running our auton routine, the limit switch no longer works, and even when pressed, the status reported in SD remains the same and does not update when running auto mode.

I think my code is correct, as we use the same commands in auto as we use for teleop. (We just run the same commands in a specific sequence) So I’m confused as to why this issue is happening, why does the limit switch refuse to work in auto?

Has anyone else ever had this issue? How has your team addressed it?

Its almost 100% an issue in your code. Without providing your code, we wont be able to help much at all beyond pure speculation.

Are you using a default command on the subsystem with the limit switches? If so, that is likely your challenge. Default commands work, but only if NOTHING in your ENTIRE auto requires the subsystem.

Ok, this might sound a bit weird, but we’ve actually fixed our issue, and it wasn’t an electrical or programming thing.

When this issue occured, it actually prevented us from performing other commands aswell like running our shooter motor or drivetrain etc.

I wasn’t exactly sure what this issue was, until I opened up the DS Timing Window, and I saw there were huge lag spikes.

My next step was to check task manager and I had found some apps on our laptop that were interfering with communications, and I terminated those processes and deleted those apps.

So, it was really just naughty applications running in the background causing communication issues. Without them running, we no longer have this issue.

While you are fiddling around in laptop settings turn off the “sleep on lid close”. If a robot hits the alliance wall hard enough it can jiggle lids closed.
